original:
I spoke with DWP's current maintenance contact about this charger today. They know there is an issue (missing pin from the plug) and are waiting on the vendor (Nissan I guess) to get out there to fix it.

He said this week LADWP has internal meetings to start having a dedicated person to manage maintenance for LADWP chargers, which would hopefully include a maintenance contact with Nissan so issues will be fixed more promptly.

If you do use this number, please be courteous and know that he is NOT the one fixing these issues, but he is helping coordinate maintenance and ultimately a maintenance contract with Nissan. He was very informative and I thanked him for the info!

Ruslan Sibagatullin
213 367 4850
augmented: I spoke today with the current maintenance contact from DWP about this charger. You know there is a problem (missing pin on the plug) and are waiting for the salesman (Nissan, I suspect) to fix it. He said that LADWP is holding internal meetings this week to start with a dedicated person for the maintenance of LADWP chargers, who will hopefully get a maintenance contact with Nissan so that problems can be fixed faster. If you are using this number, please be polite and know that he is NOT the one to fix these problems, but he is helping to coordinate the maintenance and ultimately a maintenance contract with Nissan. He was very informative and I thanked him for the information! Ruslan Sibagatullin213 367 4850

original:
Great spot for Solar Charge ....

The 100k array is laterally pumping electrons into your battery during the day.  
I paid for my first charge on the beginning  of my 210 mile return trip to Monterey.  I used the new SMUD (Sacramento) Fast SAE and Chademo.  They just charge 20 cents/kwh and still make 100% profit on the power. (about $2)  I was not required to join "Greenlots" but the guy on the phone was so nice I probably will since they seem about the same as Chargepoint and offer reasonable rates.  The security guard is very nice guy who "would not really notice" a non-employ in the L2 charge lot (20+ chargers/spots mostly empty!   There is also a L2 port at the east side of visitor lot but it is frequently used by EV employs for prime parking.
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

Other nearby Nissan Leaf dealer charge info below:

I recommend  Davis Nissan for a better sales/customer service experience.   They not only offer free Chademo but want to come out and chat EV and help you plug in.

Both Roseville Future and Elk Grove nissan must be some of the worst dealers in California.  I recommend a free L2 charge on these facilities and spreading the word about Davis Nissan.


Roseville Future and Elk Grove  Nissan dealer does not seem to want to promote EVs.  They have sold rights of the ChAdeMo fast charge over to  EVgo.  It will cost you about 10$ per 50% charge.  What a bummer for leaf buyers who bought from these dealers.  They also offer man "plans" like AT&T at even more cost such as the $15/month plan with $29 cancelation fee;-(((

Elk Grove :  There are also only 4 spaces for 5 charges.  I had to block the ChadeMO so I could do a free L2 charge.

The sales manger was not really interested in any of my comments for creating and supporting his leaf customers.  They did have all these "customer appreciation event" signs in the lobby.  I guess it must be more about training for manager;-)
augmented: I paid my first fee at the start of my 210-mile return trip to Monterey. I used the new SMUD (Sacramento) Fast SAE and Chademo. They charge only 20 cents / kWh and still make 100% profit on electricity. (about $2) I was not required to join "green lots," but the guy on the phone was so kind that I will probably appear as similar to Chargepoint and offer reasonable prices. The security guard is very nice and would "not really notice" that a non-employee in the L2 loading bay (20 + chargers / spots) is mostly empty! There is also an L2 port on the east side of the visitor booth, but it is often used by EV staff for first-class parking.

original:
Updated Thursday, July 3, 2014 @ 9:45 AM EDT:

Connecticut DOT & Tesla Motors are jointly updating charging signage at the 2 Greenwich Service Plazas on the Merritt Pkwy (CT-15).  Due to high parking stall utilization at these plazas, posted stalls shall be used for SHARED parking or EV charging:  

Stalls are FIRST-COME, FIRST-SERVE; 
Vehicle may EITHER park 15 minutes OR CHARGE 45 minutes; 
Vehicle must vacate stall after EITHER park OR charge cycle is complete.

Thank you for your cooperation.  Please direct any comments or questions to:

Richard C. Hanley, P.E. 
Connecticut DOT 
Telephone: 860-594-2887 
Email: Richard.Hanley@CT.gov
augmented: Updated Thursday, July 3, 2014 at 9: 45 AM EDT: Connecticut DOT & Tesla Motors will jointly update the charging signs at 2 Greenwich Service Plazas on Merritt Pkwy (CT-15).Due to the high occupancy rates at these locations, the stalls will be used for shared parking or charging of electric vehicles: The stalls are FIRST-COME, FIRST-SERVE; the vehicle can park for 15 minutes OR LIMITED 45 minutes; the vehicle must leave the stall after the EITHER parking OR charging cycle is complete. Thank you for your cooperation. Comments or questions should be directed to: Richard C. Hanley, P.E. Connecticut DOT Phone: 860-594-2887 Email: Richard.Hanley @ CT.gov

original:
Nissan NCTC

2015-05-10
Plugshare and EZ-Charge apps under their current design should have separate listings for L3s so that status (like under repair) and alerts (like all stations in use and station has become available) make sense for real human EV users.    
                                                 Nissan advertises 30 minutes free with NCTC on L3s. Unfortunately, they are failing to be honest in several ways:

0. Many stations are out of order, but not listed as such on the advertising posters in Nissan dealerships or in the EZ-Charge app, which has a special icon for under repair. In Phoenix, about 5 of 21 stations are currently out of order but still using the normally working icon.

1. They do not provide 30-minute free sessions.

2. They fail to time the sessions for you.

3. They fail to cut off the session at 30 minutes.

4. If you go over, they charge you $7. This requires you to leave work or whatever you are doing, exactly in time to cut it off. If you leave too early, then you cut your session short. If you leave right on time, you must still cut your session a little short to avoid going over the 30 minutes on your own timing.

5. They refuse to document or provide measures for when the timer starts and when it ends.

6. When touch screens do not work, you cannot use NCTC over app or telephone. They say you can dispute it later, but their dispute process is opaque and time consuming. That is not a free 30-minute charge, either.

7. What they should have done, and what they probably originally meant to do, is simply provide $7 fast charges for free to NCTC customers.
augmented: Nissan NCTC2015-05-10Plugshare and EZ-Charge apps in their current design should have separate listings for L3s, so status (as in repair) and alarms (as in all stations that are in use and station has become available) make sense for real human users of electric vehicles. Nissan advertises 30 minutes free with NCTC on L3s. Unfortunately, they are not honest in several respects: 0. Many stations are out of service, but not listed as such on the billboards in Nissan dealerships or in the EZ-Charge app, which has a special icon for repairs. In Phoenix, about 5 of 21 stations are currently out of service, but still use the normally functioning tool.1. They do not offer 30-minute free sittings.2. They fail to schedule the sessions for you.3. They do not interrupt the session after 30 minutes.4. If you pass, they charge you $7. This requires you to stop work or whatever you do just in time to exit them.

original: Tom, it is a metro station. People drive many miles to get there,plug-in  and take a train to work or to get someplace far away. I'm lobbying metro to change the signs to reflect the real purpose of the lot which is to allow daily EV metro commuters the ability to have a charged car when they return back from their journey. Metro should have installed many L1 outlets to accompany the L2 so people can top off via L2 at the end of the day & use L1 during the day.
augmented: Tom, it's a subway station: people travel many miles to get there, get on the train and take the train to work or to a far away place. I want the subway to change the signage so that it reflects the real purpose of the lot, which is to allow daily commuters with electric vehicles to have a recharged car on the way back from their trip. Subway should have set up many L1 outlets to accompany the L2 so that people can lock up on the L2 at the end of the day and use L1 during the day.
